title: Merowe Dam
long_title: Construction of the Merowe hydroelectric dam
description:
The Merowe dam in northern Sudan, which lies about 350 km north of the capital Khartoum, is currently the biggest contemporary hydropower project in Africa.

Built by Chinese, German and French companies, Chinaâ€™s government contributed $608 million to build its power station and transmission lines. Built on the Nile's fourth cataract between 2003 and 2009, the dam created a reservoir with a length of 174 km. With a capacity of 1,250 megawatts, the project has doubled Sudan's electricity generation capacity. But the project was not without controversy.

The UN reported that 60,000 civilians were displaced by the construction and have ended up living in inhospitable desert locations. Sudanese civilians protested the project's execution from the start, and those protests even escalated into bloody clashes. In April 2006, three people were killed and more than 50 injured.

Photo: nasamarshall/Flickr

title: Africa Union Headquarters
long_title: Expansion of AU headquarters and conference center
description:
In January 2012, the Chinese-built African Union Headquarters was opened in the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa. The huge complex cost $200 million and China picked up the whole bill. Jia Qinglin, a senior Chinese government official, called it "a cornerstone of China to further strengthen cooperation with Africa."

But Chika Ezeanya, an African writer, said the shining building was a tragedy. "African countries collectively descend to a new low on the global index of state sovereignty and territorial integrity", she said. "It is impossible that in 2012 a building as symbolic as the African Union HQ is designed, built and maintained by a foreign country, it does not matter which."

Journalists like Antoine Lokongo reminded her that Ethiopian experts were involved in the coordination and a "team of up to 1,200 Chinese and Ethiopian workers laboured around the clock â€¦ to finish it on schedule".

Photo: UNAMID/Flickr

title: Thika Superhighway
long_title: Expansion of Nairobi-Thika road Section three
description:
Thika Road is an eight-lane highway that runs from the Kenyan capital Nairobi to the outskirts of Thika. President Mwai Kibaki officially inaugurated the superhighway, in some sections 16 lanes across, in November 2012, hoping it would help boost East Africaâ€™s economic fortunes.

The Export-Import Bank of China provided $100 million for it to be completed by Shenli, Sinohydro Corp, and China Wu Yi â€“ all Chinese companies. The contractors employed more than 4,000 people for the construction, a huge economic boost. The finished road, though, has been criticised for being prone to flooding.

Photo: Wikipedia

title: Internet Backbone
description:
China is helping Africa to strengthen its Internet capabilities. For example, the Chinese are building a broadband backbone that will cover 10,674 km through Tanzania and Rwanda, providing connections to Burundi, Uganda, Zambia, Malawi and Kenya.

The scheme was projected to cost $170 million, partially financed with soft loans from the Export-Import Bank of China. The China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation, which is a subsidiary of China Telecom, will carry out the project along with Chinaâ€™s Huawei firm.

Photo: 13kingdoms/Flickr

title: Confucius Institute
long_title: Confucius Institute founded at University of Zimbabwe
description:
In 2006, a Confucius Institute was established at the University of Zimbabwe. Confucius Institutes aim to promote Chinese language and culture, support the teaching of Chinese internationally, and facilitate cultural exchanges. They are Chinaâ€™s answer to Germany's Goethe Institutes or the UKâ€™s British Councils.

Beijing has now built 45 such centres in Africa. As various cultural exchanges have improved Chinaâ€™s global image, some argue that Confucius Institutes are emblematic of Chinaâ€™s attempts to exercise soft power on the continent. However, others say locals are demanding, and benefiting from, them.

Photo: rob_web

title: Umbeluzi Research Institute
long_title: China builds Agricultural Research Center/Agriculture Station
description:
In 2011, a Chinese Agricultural Research Centre was opened in Boane, Mozambique. The centre is one of 20 China is building across Africa as part of its aid program.

Loro Horta, research associate at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies in Singapore, has accused China of land-grabbing and has mentioned such research centers - along with land deals - as evidence of a Chinese plan to transform Mozambique into an agricultural colony. But such accusations have been strongly criticised by other academics, including Deborah Brautigam, a professor at John Hopkins University.

Photo: Wikipedia

title: Platinum Mines
description:
In May 2010, the Financial Times reported that China's state-owned miner Jinchuan and the China Development Bank were set to pump $877 million into South Africa's platinum industry. The deal would mark China's second-largest investment in Africa outside the energy sector.

Jinchuan - one of Chinaâ€™s largest mining groups - plans to buy a 51% stake for $277 million in Wesizwe, a small South African platinum developer. The CDB will raise $650 million in project finance to develop the new Bakubung platinum mine, located west of Pretoria. According to Wesizwe CEO, Jianke Gao, the capital cost of the Bakubung mine is expected to escalate to $1 billion.

Photo: Wikipedia

title: YaoundÃ© Stadium
description:
Today, 34 countries in Africa have Chinese-built stadiums, mostly given as gifts or financed with soft loans. It has become such a common phenomenon that the term â€˜stadium diplomacyâ€™ has been coined. Some analysts, though, believe the stadiums are built in return for access to natural resources and votes at the United Nations.

YaoundÃ© Multi-functional Stadium was opened in 2009 by Cameroon President Paul Biya, and is the largest of its kind in central Africa. It is regarded as a symbol of friendship between China and Cameroon and has a seated capacity of more than 5,000. It cost $26 million to build.

Photo: okabol/Flickr

title: Lagos-Kano Railway
description:
The Chinese Civil Engineering Construction Corporation was awarded the contract for the modernization of Nigeria's 1,313 km railway from Lagos to Kano. The journey currently takes 31 hours, but the government plans to reduce it to 24. The project is worth $8 billion and China has soft-loaned the Nigerian government at least $500 million to finance the project.

In addition to boosting trade, some believe that the train can help unite Nigeria. The country has been wracked by periodic episodes of violence for decades. Nigeria's 150 million people are divided between the mostly Muslim north and Christian and animist south.

Photo: jbdodane/Flickr
